questions.stem: When a pedestrian steps into a marked crosswalk in your lane, you should:

choices.text: Sound your horn and pass carefully.
Change lanes quickly to avoid stopping.
Stop and yield the right-of-way until the crosswalk is clear.
Continue at the speed limit if the light is green.

questions.explanation: Drivers must yield to pedestrians in marked and unmarked crosswalks and wait until the crosswalk is clear.

questions.stem: You are turning right at an intersection. A pedestrian begins crossing in the crosswalk you will enter. What must you do?

choices.text: Honk to warn and proceed.
Stop and let the pedestrian finish crossing.
Turn into the crosswalk if there is room.
Move into the bike lane to go around.

questions.explanation: When turning, you must yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk you are crossing.

questions.stem: A person with a white cane is waiting at the corner. What is the safest action?

choices.text: Stop in the crosswalk so they can feel your car.
Stop well before the crosswalk and wait; do not honk.
Wave them to cross while you roll forward.
Flash your headlights to signal them to go.

questions.explanation: Blind pedestrians with a white cane or guide dog have the right-of-way. Stop before the crosswalk and wait quietly.

questions.stem: What is the minimum space you must give when passing a bicyclist?

choices.text: 1 foot
2 feet
3 feet
6 feet

questions.explanation: California’s Three Feet for Safety rule requires at least 3 feet of clearance when passing bicyclists.

questions.stem: Before a right turn where there is a bike lane, you should:

choices.text: Turn directly across the bike lane without merging.
Merge into the bike lane about 200 feet before the turn and yield to bicyclists.
Stop in the bike lane to block bikes so you can turn.
Speed up to get ahead of bicyclists and then turn.

questions.explanation: You may enter the bike lane near the intersection to turn right, but you must yield to bicyclists already in the lane.

questions.stem: Opening your car door next to traffic is only legal when:

choices.text: You open it quickly and step out fast.
No traffic or bicyclists will be affected.
You leave it open so others can see you.
The bike lane is present.

questions.explanation: It is illegal to open a door unless it is reasonably safe and does not interfere with traffic, including bicyclists.

questions.stem: Which statement is true about motorcycles?

choices.text: They can stop as quickly as large trucks.
They are small and harder to see; look twice before turning.
You may share a lane with a motorcycle.
They must always ride in the far right lane.

questions.explanation: Motorcycles are smaller and easy to overlook, especially at left turns.

questions.stem: In California, lane splitting by motorcyclists is:

choices.text: Illegal at all times.
Legal; drivers should not block or interfere.
Allowed only at night.
Allowed only in school zones.

questions.explanation: Lane splitting by riders is legal. Drivers must not block or discourage it and should hold a steady path.

questions.stem: What following distance should you use behind a motorcycle in good conditions?

choices.text: 1 second
2 seconds
4 seconds or more
No specific gap is needed

questions.explanation: Increase space behind motorcycles; a 4‑second following distance provides a safety buffer.

questions.stem: Flashing yellow lights on a school bus mean you should:

choices.text: Speed up to pass before it stops.
Prepare to stop; the bus is about to stop.
Ignore them if you are on the opposite side.
Honk to warn children.

questions.explanation: Yellow flashing lights warn the bus is preparing to stop to load or unload children.

questions.stem: A school bus has flashing red lights and a stop arm extended. You must:

choices.text: Stop only if following the bus.
Stop from either direction until the lights stop flashing.
Proceed at 15 mph with caution.
Pass carefully if no children are visible.

questions.explanation: You must stop from either direction for flashing red school bus lights until the lights stop.

questions.stem: When are you NOT required to stop for a school bus with flashing red lights?

choices.text: On the opposite side of a divided highway with a physical median.
On a two‑lane road in a rural area.
When you do not see children nearby.
When you are late for school.

questions.explanation: Vehicles on the opposite side of a divided highway or road with a physical median are generally not required to stop.

questions.stem: An emergency vehicle with red lights and a siren approaches. You should:

choices.text: Stop in the intersection immediately.
Pull to the right edge and stop after clearing any intersection.
Speed up to get out of the way, even through red lights.
Continue driving until it passes you.

questions.explanation: Yield by pulling to the right and stopping. Do not stop in an intersection; clear it first.

questions.stem: At a roundabout, an emergency vehicle with siren is behind you. What should you do?

choices.text: Stop in the roundabout to yield immediately.
Exit the roundabout, then pull to the right and stop.
Change lanes inside the roundabout.
Accelerate to stay ahead.

questions.explanation: Do not stop in an intersection or roundabout. Exit first, then pull over and stop to yield.

questions.stem: The Move Over law requires you to:

choices.text: Stop in your lane whenever you see flashing lights on the shoulder.
Move to a non-adjacent lane or slow to a safe speed when passing stationary emergency or service vehicles with flashing lights.
Turn on your hazard lights and continue at the same speed.
Honk to warn workers as you pass.

questions.explanation: You must move over or slow down for stopped emergency or roadside service vehicles with flashing lights.

questions.stem: A truck’s No‑Zone refers to:

choices.text: A place where trucks cannot legally drive.
The truck’s blind spots where your car is not visible.
An area for truck-only parking.
The shoulder next to a truck.

questions.explanation: No‑Zones are large vehicle blind spots to the front, sides, and rear where you may not be seen.

questions.stem: After passing a large truck on the left, you should move back into the lane only when:

choices.text: You can see the truck’s entire front in your mirror.
You are one car length ahead.
The truck honks for you to move.
You reach the truck’s front wheel.

questions.explanation: Return to the lane only when there is ample space and you can see the truck’s front in your mirror.

questions.stem: Why is cutting in front of a truck especially dangerous?

choices.text: Trucks have better brakes than cars.
Trucks take longer to stop due to size and weight.
Truck drivers sit higher and can always see you.
It is only risky at night.

questions.explanation: Large vehicles need longer stopping distances, so cutting in can cause a rear‑end crash.

citations.section: Sharing the Road with Large Vehicles

questions.stem: Orange signs and cones ahead mean you should:

choices.text: Maintain speed to clear the area quickly.
Slow down, be ready to merge, and watch for workers.
Change lanes at the last second to get ahead.
Turn on high beams to see better.

questions.explanation: Work zones require reduced speeds, early merging, and extra attention for workers and equipment.

questions.stem: Flaggers in work zones have authority to:

choices.text: Give suggestions you may ignore.
Direct traffic with the same authority as signs and signals.
Write speeding tickets.
Close roads only at night.

questions.explanation: You must follow flagger directions; they carry the same authority as signs and signals.

questions.stem: At an active railroad crossing with flashing red lights, you must:

choices.text: Proceed if no train is visible.
Drive around the gate only if you are late.
Stop and wait until the lights stop and gates rise.
Stop on the tracks to look both ways.

questions.explanation: Never go around lowered gates. Stop and wait until signals end and the crossing is clear.

questions.stem: Your vehicle stalls on the tracks and a train is approaching. What should you do first?

choices.text: Try to restart the engine.
Stay inside and call a tow truck.
Exit everyone and run toward the train at an angle away from the tracks.
Push the car off the tracks.

questions.explanation: Get everyone out immediately and move away at an angle toward the train to avoid debris.

questions.stem: When approaching a horseback rider on the road, you should:

choices.text: Honk to alert the rider.
Pass closely to shorten time near the animal.
Slow down, give extra space, and follow the rider’s hand signals.
Drive on the shoulder to pass.

questions.explanation: Slow, give space, and follow the rider’s signals or handlers’ instructions. Avoid sudden horn use.

questions.stem: A vehicle with an orange triangular emblem ahead is moving slowly. You should:

choices.text: Expect it to travel about 25 mph or less and pass only when legal and safe.
Honk and tailgate to prompt them to speed up.
Drive on the shoulder to pass immediately.
Assume it will pull off the road quickly.

questions.explanation: The slow‑moving vehicle emblem means 25 mph or less. Pass only when it is legal and you can leave plenty of space.
